content.title: 10 Things You May Not Know About 'Wuthering Heights'

results:
Based on the search results, I found the information you were looking for about the Graham's Lady Magazine review of Wuthering Heights from 1847. 

Graham's Lady Magazine wrote: "How a human being could have attempted such a book as the present without committing suicide before he had finished a dozen chapters, is a mystery. It is a compound of vulgar depravity and unnatural horrors."

This harsh review was published when Wuthering Heights came out in December 1847. The quote you searched for appears to be from this American publication's review of Emily Brontë's novel. Graham's Lady Magazine, an American publication, stated, "It is a compound of vulgar depravity and unnatural horrors" and wondered how the author could have refrained from suicide.(no content)Wuthering Heights shocked Victorian critics with its violence, passionate characters, and amoral plot. While some reviewers admired its creativity, others downright hated it. This particular review from Graham's Lady Magazine represents one of the most scathing contemporary critiques of the novel, reflecting the Victorian era's shock at the book's unconventional and dark content.
